full_text: Switching to electric vehicles is an important part of the transition. We have supported a 5 fold increase in EV purchases since 2016 with grants. #Budget 2020 will see ‚Ç¨36m allocated in 2020
The ring-fenced funding from Carbon Tax will also be used to fund climate measures, such as: new greenways & urban cycling pathways, pilots for sustainable agricultural measures #Budget2020
It will create 70 jobs in year one rising to 100 as the programme develops. #Budget2020 #JustTransition

This programme will support the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) to restore  1,800 hectares of bog in 7 counties, resulting in 28m tonnes of carbon stored over the next 5 years. #Budget2020 #JustTransition
‚Ç¨5m for bog restoration and rehabilitation which will restore bogs to their natural habitat and become sinks that absorb carbon. #Budget2020 #JustTransition
This #JustTransition Fund targeted at the Midlands. This funding will support retraining & reskilling workers and assist local communities & businesses in the midlands to transition

This government is committed to ensuring that the most vulnerable are protected as we move away from fossil fuel. The  #Budget2020 will provide ‚Ç¨6m to a Just Transition Fund targeted at the Midlands

I am acutely aware of the impact that moving away from fossil fuels will have on some people. Just transition and protecting the most vulnerable is at the heart of the Climate Action Plan. #Budget 2020 will support those most affected
Following Advice from the Climate Change Advisory Council #Budget2020 will increase the price of carbon by ‚Ç¨6 per tonne with all money raised ring-fenced for climate action & just transition
#Budget2020 puts major focus on Climate Action. We are taking the actions needed now, to secure a sustainable, resilient Ireland for future generations
Will be on @rtetwip this morning to discuss Brexit, Budget and how we can protect those most vulnerable as we move to a low carbon economy #TWIP
We can also expect consumer prices to come down as operators work in a more competitive market

The Interconnector is likely to drive down electricity prices for the consumer through increased competition. And because Ireland will be able to join the European Internal Energy market, we can maintain higher levels of wind and renewable energy.
Once built, its 700 megawatts capacity will power 450,000 households, and help Ireland to switch to 70% renewable energy as set out in the Climate Action Plan
The ‚Ç¨1 billion Celtic Interconnector will connect Ireland‚Äôs electricity network to France via an underwater connection
The government have today confirmed a ‚Ç¨530 million investment in the Celtic Interconnector by the European Commission to link Ireland with Europe‚Äôs energy grid https://t.co/9H08OvxnIl
Not only are woodlands crucial to absorb carbon emissions, but they are essential for preserving Ireland‚Äôs biodiversity. The focus of this project is on native Irish trees and animal species.
This project is a great example of how we can better use our resources to step up our response, to what is the most crucial issue of this generation.

Launching a joint project with @BordnaMona & @coilltenews with @ADoyleTD & @creedcnw that will see bogs no longer used for peat production and transformed into rich, native woodlands. Our land is one of our most powerful tools in responding to the climate challenge. https://t.co/IZP9Ms9QUh

They cover policy areas such as poverty eradication, economic development, protection of the environment, access to health and education services, gender equality, peaceful societies and human rights. The government are committed to fully implementing the Goals by 2030.
The 17 Sustainable Development Goals are an ambitious set of targets, covering the social, economic and environmental requirements for a sustainable future.

The chosen champions are organisations who are leading by example in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. They will raise public awareness of the Goals, and illustrate practical ways in which organisations and individuals can contribute to achieving the Goals.

At the #ploughing in Carlow launching the Sustainable Development Goal Champions #SDGsIrl #SDGChampions  These are 12 leaders from across society chosen to drive forward Sustainable Development Goals https://t.co/oybL8SnFps
Much of our food waste is avoidable and there is great scope for this to be reduced as well as eliminating plastics that are not recyclable in our food packaging
Reducing our food waste at each stage of the food chain will result in savings for producers, retails and consumers

Banning a range of single-use plastics, new fees on non-recyclable plastics, like on food packaging in supermarkets, and halving food waste will be vital to ensuring the Climate Action Plan succeeds. Hosting an important summit today about implementing the change https://t.co/Is3rdPPtUT

When we succeed Ireland will be a better place with cleaner air, warmer homes, more resilient enterprises, more secure incomes and jobs and a sustainable relationship with the world around us, that we can proudly pass on to the next generation.

This is an opportunity to discuss how we can undertake the transition and exploit the new opportunities opened up by our determined aim to lower greenhouse gas emissions and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050

Increasing the number of on-street charge points will remove a key barrier to the uptake of electric vehicles. In many cases, on-street charge points may be integrated with street lighting in a single lamppost.
We will also introduce new regulations to require non-domestic buildings with over 20 car parking spaces to install charging points

I announced today a new scheme to support the roll out of 1,000 electric vehicle charging points by local authorities. One of a number of measures we are taking to support electric vehicle roll out. Builds on Climate Action Fund investment announced earlier this year
Should be a great event üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è https://t.co/8IXK6xidxH
I can assure contractors and home owners that the October deadline to complete retrofitting works will not apply, with completion dates likely to move into 2020 for new grants offered.
The Task Force will be chaired by the Secretary General of the Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment.
This new model of retrofitting will be vital to achieve the target set out in the Climate Action Plan to deliver 500,000 homes.

The new model will group home retrofits in the same area together to reduce costs, develop easy pay back mechanisms like through your electricity bill, and get access to new smart finance and loan options.

The retrofitting of 500,000 homes, to make them warmer and more energy efficient, is a key action under the Climate Action Plan. These upgrades will help deliver on our climate commitments, which will result in warmer homes & will save homeowners money via cheaper energy bills
I will be discussing this on @RTENewsAtOne shortly

Given the huge level of interest in this scheme, I believe that putting applications received on hold while a new review is carried out is not providing enough certainty given the huge amount of work & energy that home owners & contractors have done to get applications in

Anyone who has submitted an application by the closing date can be assured that their application will be assessed and honoured in line with the existing terms and conditions of the scheme. No work should commence on site until you receive approval to proceed.

This morning I met with the CEO of @SEAI_ie, Jim Gannon, to discuss the next steps for the deep retrofit pilot scheme. I asked the SEAI to process all applications for the deep retrofit pilot scheme which were received before the July deadline.

The current provision of free TV licences to those in receipt of the Household Benefits Package will continue. The option of purchasing TV licences at post offices will remain regardless of who the successful awardee of the contract is.
This is a fundamental reform that will take time to develop, but it will future proof the funding model, taking account of changes in technology and in how content is now consumed.
It is also clear that due to the nature of technological change and the movement towards digital devices, the design of the T.V. licence fee will have to change.

Most people pay their T.V. licence fee. However, we still see approximately 12% evasion which we need to address. By tendering for a contract of 5 years, this will allow the awarded body the chance to invest in a robust collection service
The collection of the T.V. licence fee will be put out to public tender later this year.

It will allow for the creation of a new funding scheme that would allow the granting of bursaries to journalists in local or community radio stations. We must support our local community radio stations and independent broadcasters.

Today, I am publishing the Broadcasting (Amendment) Bill 2019. This Bill will enable the broadcasting levy to be reduced for all broadcasters and for some community broadcasters to be exempted entirely.
However, we must recognise that the landscape in which broadcasters operate is undergoing a transformation and that this gives rise to new challenges.
Public service broadcasting is more important now than ever. Independent, objective reporting of domestic and international affairs is crucial.
Looking forward to this. Young people have led the way with their passion. We must act now to secure a more sustainable future for the generations which come after us https://t.co/CR2Yx5t700
This feedback will be taken into account as we develop our 2020 Plan.

While the focus of the recently published Plan has been on the reduction in Greenhouse Gas Emissions, the Advisory Council‚Äôs report is a timely reminder that we must also ensure that appropriate consideration is given to embedding robust adaptation measures across the system.
The intention for the Climate Action Plan is that it is a living, evolving plan that adapts in response to feedback and experience.

While I recognise that the Council has not yet had the opportunity to evaluate the Plan in full, I am pleased with the Council‚Äôs supportive comments following its publication & look forward to their full review & feedback, which will be important for future iterations of the Plan
The advice of the Council has had a substantial influence on the development of the recently published Climate Action Plan.
In relation to the publication of the Climate Change Advisory Council‚Äôs report, I want to acknowledge the work of the Council in producing this important review

The time for rhetoric is over. Sustained, consistent action across every sector, driven from the highest level of government is the only way we will meet this challenge. It will define us as a generation #MacGill2019

We will be living more connected, healthier lives. Our air will be cleaner. Our homes will be warmer.  We will look back at the disposable culture we have now with disbelief. We will have enterprises able to compete and create jobs in a very changed world #MacGill2019

Ultimately, this is not about our ranking in some European Union or UN league table about ourselves and our children. It is about the resilience of our homes, our farms, our enterprises and our planet for our children and the generation which come after #MacGill2019
A new toolbox will be required. One that leverages aid, trade, research and compacts in the pursuit of a radical shift towards decarbonization #MacGill2019

This challenge is also a test of the creative capacity for international cooperation. The European Union must seek to lead the change that is required and our capacity for solidarity will no doubt be crucial in this endeavour #MacGill2019
To sustain this contract, we will engage in continuous monitoring and open feedback to ensure the policies we have in place are the best ones for our country #MacGill2019

It is built on three principles: pursuing the policies which offer the least burden & greatest opportunity; recognizing need to support those most exposed & least equipped to meet the challenge and ensuring every section of society make their fair contribution, while govt leads
This Plan recognizes the balanced nature of the social contract which we need to strike with the Irish public #MacGill2019

Symbolic gestures will do nothing to solve the climate crisis. There are no silver bullets. Responding to this crisis requires action across the board, led by the government, with structures in place to ensure accountability #MacGill2019

As we saw with the Action Plan for Jobs, fundamental reform can only be driven by sustained, consistent action. A strong governance framework and oversight to ensure implementation set this Plan apart #MacGill2019

No new car purchased from that year on, will be fuelled by fossils, compared to 98% that are purchased today. All the plastic in your local supermarket will be fully recyclable. Food waste will be halved. 30% of our homes will be fuelled by renewable heat vs 2% today #MacGill2019

The Plan envisages radical change. In 2030, we will have 5 times the amount of renewables on our grid that we have today (requiring capacity to peak at 95% electricity generation from renewable sources). 33% of the cars on our road will be fully electric or hybrids (1/2)
An immediate start must be made because the longer we put off action, the harder it will be and the more irreversible damages will have been done #MacGill2019

Now, for the first time ever, we know the least cost, least burden roadmap of actions which will ensure we reach our 2030 climate commitments and put us on a trajectory to reach net zero emissions by 2050 #MacGill2019

Ireland has not been lacking in ambition, but in delivery.  There has been no coherent strategy that would in fact deliver on commitments made.  We cannot countenance another such failure. That is why the government‚Äôs Climate Action Plan has taken a completely different approach

Climate disruption is the biggest challenge facing this generation.  Previously Ireland set a target of a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2020. However current forecasts suggest that only a 1% reduction will be delivered. #MacGill2019

We will do this through the development of an offshore wind sector, onshore wind and solar power. We will also be removing coal and peat from our electricity generation system.

Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) is an air pollutant associated with urban areas, strongly linked with traffic emissions. Diesel vehicles have historically far higher nitrogen dioxide emissions than other combustion engines, especially for older vehicles.

This underlines the importance of implementing the actions contained in the Climate Action Plan. A new cycling project office and a park and ride office with new 5 year strategies. 180,000 EVs on our roads by 2025. Low emission zones. No new fossil fuel car sold post 2030. https://t.co/YbyvEuBss3

Will be on @TodaySOR shortly to discuss my proposals to keep children safe online https://t.co/tMLJu21WYq

I held a short six week consultation on the proposals which ended mid-April. All submissions to this consultation will be published next week. The issues raised by those who made submissions will be considered in the context of drafting heads of bill to bring to government.

I brought forward proposals for a new Online Safety Law in March. This new law would place clear expectations on social media firms to keep children safe online and would be overseen by a new Online Safety Commissioner

Every public body will be given a climate action mandate by their line Minister to prioritise climate action #ClimatePlan2019

#ClimatePlan2019 will deliver a new Retrofit Plan to retrofit 500,000 homes, with large groups of houses being retrofitted by the same contractor to reduce costs, smart finance, and easy pay back methods
Reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture will be achieved by developing sustainable opportunities for family farms #ClimatePlan2019
There will be 5 year carbon budgets #ClimatePlan2019

#ClimatePlan2019 set sectoral targets for every relevant sector: for housing, transport, heating, agriculture, and the public sector, with the relevant Minister responsible for delivering on the target, with penalities if they are not met. These targets will be set independently
#ClimatePlan2019 will expand our network of cycling paths and ‚ÄòPark and Ride‚Äô facilities, helping to ease congestion
No new petrol/diesel cars will sold in Ireland from 2030 #ClimatePlan2019
#ClimatePlan2019 will deliver a nationwide charging network, an electric vehicle scrappage scheme
#ClimatePlan2019 will bring 950,000 electric vehicles onto our roads
#ClimatePlan2019 will increase our renewable sources of electricity from 30% to 70% by 2030
#ClimatePlan2019 will establish a new microgeneration scheme, allowing homeowners to generate their own electricity and sell what they don‚Äôt use back to the national grid
#ClimatePlan2019 will eliminate non-recyclable plastic and impose higher fees on the production of materials which are difficult to recycle
Ultimately this is about securing a better, healthier, more resilient future for the country #ClimatePlan2019

Today we are publishing the Climate Action Plan to tackle climate breakdown. It sets out our roadmap.  It identifies how Ireland will achieve its 2030 targets for carbon emissions, and puts us on a trajectory to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 #ClimatePlan2019
We have a short window of opportunity to reverse this trend. The time to act is now #ClimatePlan2019

At a time when we should be radically reducing our reliance on carbon, Ireland‚Äôs greenhouse gas emissions have been rising rapidly. We are currently 85% dependent on fossil fuels #ClimatePlan2019 https://t.co/XbaoTY3LIo
